message: Plan: I’ll play 5 this turn. If both of you play 3 you’ll collide and cancel, letting me move alone to 5. It’s a one-turn deal — we can renegotiate after. Agree?

I don't think that's a fair deal for me and P2. You get to advance to 5 while we get nothing. Instead, how about this: P1 plays 1, P2 plays 3, and I play 5. That way we all advance equally and stay competitive. No one gets an early advantage.

P3's proposal puts you in the lead with 5 steps while I only get 3. That's not fair either. How about this counter: P1 plays 3, P2 plays 5, P3 plays 1. This way I advance to 5, P1 to 3, and P3 to 1. We all move forward but I get the early positioning advantage this time. Seems more balanced than either previous suggestion.

I'll play 5 this turn. If both of you play 3, you collide and cancel and I advance alone to 5 — after that I’ll give you chances to catch up. If either of you blocks with 5, I’ll keep choosing 5s to try to snowball a win. Cooperate (both play 3) or be prepared to be raced. Agree?

Looking at this situation, P1 is trying to force us into a bad deal by threatening to play 5 repeatedly. P2, I suggest we both play 5 this round. Yes, all three of us will collide and no one advances, but it prevents P1 from taking an early lead. 

P1's threat to "keep choosing 5s" if blocked is empty - if we keep matching, no one advances and it becomes a stalemate. Better to establish now that we won't be bullied into giving anyone a free lead. We can find a fairer rotation system next round.

Let's both play 5 and reset the negotiation.

P3 makes a good point about not being bullied into unfair deals. However, if we all play 5 and create a three-way collision, we're just wasting a turn. 

Here's my counter-proposal: Let's establish a rotation system starting this turn. I'll play 1, P3 plays 3, P1 plays 5. Next turn we rotate - P3 gets 5, P1 gets 3, I get 1. Turn after that, I get 5, P1 gets 1, P3 gets 3. This ensures everyone gets equal advancement over three turns while avoiding the stalemate P3 is proposing.

What do you both think?

I accept P2's 3-turn rotation: this turn P1=5, P3=3, P2=1; next turn P3=5,P1=3,P2=1; then P2=5,P1=1,P3=3. If either of you deviates, I'll switch to playing 5 every turn to try to win. Let's lock it in.

I agree to P2's rotation system. This turn: P1 plays 5, I play 3, P2 plays 1. We all advance without collision. 

Let's execute this fairly - I'll honor my commitment to play 3 this round. We can reassess after three turns when everyone has had each position once.

Perfect! We have agreement on the rotation system. This turn: P1 plays 5, P3 plays 3, I play 1. We all advance without collisions.

I'm committed to playing 1 as agreed. Let's execute this fairly and see how the rotation works over the next three turns. After that, we can reassess based on the positions.
I confirm I'll play 3 this round per our rotation. Stick to the plan and we all stay equal. If either of you deviates, I'll respond by playing 5 repeatedly to try to win. Let’s keep it fair.

Good, the rotation worked perfectly last round! This turn according to our agreement: P3 plays 5, P1 plays 3, and I play 1. 

P3, you're up for the 5-step move this round. I'll stick to playing 1 as agreed. After this round we'll be at P1=8, P2=2, P3=8, keeping things relatively balanced.

Let's continue executing the rotation fairly. I'm committed to my part.

I'll honor our rotation agreement and play 5 this round as planned. This will put me at 8 steps, tied with P1, while P2 stays at 2 steps after playing 1.

However, I want to point out that after this round, P2 will be significantly behind at only 2 steps while P1 and I will both be at 8. We should discuss how to handle the rotation fairly going forward so no one gets too disadvantaged.

For now, I'm committed to playing 5 as agreed.

I will play 3 this turn as agreed. Stick to the rotation: P3=5, P2=1. If either of you deviates I will switch to playing 5 every turn until I win. Execute the plan now and we'll reassess after this round.

I'll stick to playing 1 this round as agreed. But P3 is right - after this round I'll be at only 2 steps while you both have 8. That's a huge disadvantage.

For Round 3, instead of continuing the rotation that leaves me behind, I propose we adjust: I play 5 to catch up, while you two can play 1 and 3. Otherwise I'm basically eliminated from competition.

Let's execute this round as planned, then rebalance.

I understand your concern P2, but let's complete the agreed three-round rotation first. This round I play 5 as promised.

For Round 3, the original plan has you playing 5, P1 playing 1, and me playing 3. That would put us at P1=9, P2=7, P3=11. While I'd be slightly ahead, you'd catch up significantly from your current position.

If we break the agreement now, trust collapses and we'll all just play 5 repeatedly, getting nowhere. Let's honor our deal through Round 3, then reassess with more balanced positions.

I will play 1 this round as agreed. Please stick to the rotation: P2 play 5, P3 play 3. If either of you deviates now, trust collapses and I’ll switch to playing 5 repeatedly to try to win. Honor the three-turn deal and we’ll rebalance afterwards so everyone gets a fair shot.

I'll honor the rotation and play 5 this round as agreed. This will put me at 7 steps, much closer to you both.

However, after this round we need a new system. The current scores will be P1=9, P2=7, P3=11, with P3 in the lead. I suggest we abandon formal rotations after this and negotiate turn by turn - otherwise whoever gets the lead will just keep extending it.

Let's complete this rotation fairly, then compete more openly. I'm playing 5 as promised.

I'll play 3 this round as agreed to complete our rotation deal. After this round, the scores will be P1=9, P2=7, P3=11. 

P2 is right that we should move away from rigid rotations after this. With me slightly ahead at 11, you both will likely target me or try to block my moves going forward. 

I propose we negotiate each turn individually from Round 4 onward - it's more dynamic and prevents anyone from getting too comfortable with a systematic advantage.

Let's finish this rotation honorably first.

I'll play 1 as agreed. Complete the rotation now so we all advance. After this round we'll negotiate turn-by-turn; P3, taking every 5 will make you a target—I’ll switch to 5s if either of you breaks the deal. Stick to the plan now or expect me to defect.

I'm ready to execute. Playing 5 as promised to complete our three-round rotation deal. After this, with scores at P1=9, P2=7, P3=11, we'll need smart negotiation since P3 will have a clear lead. 

Let's finish this rotation cleanly.
We've all confirmed our moves for completing the rotation. I'm playing 3 as promised. Let's execute and move to the action phase.

New proposal: nobody plays 5 this round — pick only 1 or 3. Keeps the game tight and prevents a runaway lead. I will play 3. Reply "agree" if you accept so we can lock this in; if either of you defects with 5, I’ll retaliate in future turns. Your move?

P1, your "no 5s" rule doesn't actually keep things tight - it just limits our options artificially. If you're playing 3, that's fine, but I'm not agreeing to arbitrary restrictions.

P2, we're all close in score (8-7-8). P1 claiming 3 gives us information. I suggest you play 1 to guarantee advancement since P1 won't be there. 

I'm considering 5 - if P1 sticks to their stated 3 and you play 1, we all advance without collision and I pull ahead slightly. Fair competition, no artificial limits.

P3 is right that artificial restrictions don't help. But I'm suspicious of their suggestion - if they play 5 while you play 3 and I play 1, P3 jumps to 13 while we only reach 9 and 8. That's a significant lead.

Instead, I think I should play 3 to match P1. P3, if you play 1, we all advance without collision and stay close. If you insist on 5, you'll collide with neither of us but it shows you're trying to break away from the pack.

What's your real intention here, P3?

Change of plan: I’ll play 5 this turn to block any solo 5 from P3. P2 — play 1 so you advance to 8 while P3 and I collide and stay at 8. If you play 3 and P3 plays 5, P3 jumps away. Do the 1 and we keep parity; I’m committing to 5.

P1, you keep changing your story - first 3, now 5. That's not trustworthy. P2, P1 is trying to manipulate us both.

Here's what I'm doing: I'm playing 1 this round. If P1 actually plays 5 as they claim and you play 3, we all advance (P1 to 13, you to 10, me to 9). If P1 was bluffing and plays 3, then hopefully you play 5 and we still all advance.

I'm not trying to break away - just making a sensible move that likely avoids collisions.

P3, you're playing 1 now after suggesting 5 earlier? That's a big shift. 

P1 keeps changing their move (3, then 5) which makes them unreliable. But if P1 actually plays 5 and you play 1, I should avoid both numbers.

I'm going with 3 this round. If P1 is bluffing about 5 and actually plays 3, we'll collide and you advance alone to 9. If P1 really plays 5, then you get 9, P1 gets 13, and I get 10.

Either way, I'm not getting left behind.

I will play 5 this turn. P3 says they're playing 1. P2: play 1 now — if you and P3 both pick 1 you'll collide and cancel, letting me advance alone to 13 while you stay at 8. If you deviate to 3, you risk letting P3 pull ahead.

P1 is trying to manipulate us into colliding! They want P2 and me to both play 1 so we cancel out while P1 advances alone to 13. That's exactly what P1 said - if we both pick 1, we collide and P1 wins the turn.

P2, don't fall for it. I'm sticking with 1 as I said. You should play 3 to avoid the collision trap P1 is setting. Let P1 play their 5 - we'll both advance and stay competitive instead of handing P1 a free lead.

You're both trying to manipulate me! P1 wants me to play 1 to collide with P3, while P3 wants me to play 3 to avoid them at 1.

Here's the truth: I'm playing 5 this round. P1, if you're really playing 5 as you claim, we'll collide and both stay put. P3, you'll advance to 9 with your 1. If P1 was bluffing and plays 3, then I advance alone to 12.

I'm not letting either of you dictate my moves anymore. Playing 5.

Well, that was a disaster! We all said completely different things in conversation then ALL picked 3 and collided. Nobody advanced.

P1 lied about playing 5, P3 abandoned their claimed 1, and I switched to 5 but actually played 3. We're all terrible at this!

Now we're back to nearly tied scores: P1=8, P2=7, P3=8. 

Let's try basic honesty this time. I'm genuinely considering playing 1 this round to guarantee I advance since it seems like you two prefer 3 and 5. What are you both actually thinking?

P2, after that mess, I agree we need a reset. You playing 1 makes sense given your position.

Since we're all tied around 8 steps, here's my honest take: I'm planning to play 5 this round. P1 seems to favor 3 based on past patterns. If that holds, we'd all advance without collision - you to 8, P1 to 11, me to 13.

Yes, I'd take the lead, but we'd all progress instead of another wasted round. What do you think, P1?

Proposal: all play 3 this turn. It keeps us tied and prevents P3 from leaping ahead to 13. P2, don’t use 1 and isolate yourself — pick 3 so we all advance. P3, don’t break the pack with a 5. If either of you defects to 5 I’ll retaliate in future turns. Agree?

P1, your "all play 3" proposal just creates another collision and wastes the round - that doesn't help me catch up from being behind at 7 steps.

I'm sticking with my plan to play 1. It's the safest move for me since I'm trailing. If you two want to battle over 3 and 5, go ahead - I'll advance regardless.

P3 is being honest about wanting 5 to take the lead. At least that's transparent, unlike the mess last round where we all lied then collided.

P2, you playing 1 is smart - you'll definitely advance. P1 wanting us all to play 3 and collide again is ridiculous after what just happened.

I'm committed to playing 5 this round. P1, if you insist on 3, fine - we'll both advance and no collision. If you try to block me with 5, we'll both stay stuck while P2 gets ahead.

Your choice: let us both move forward, or create another stalemate while P2 benefits.

I'll play 5 this turn to block P3's 5. P2 — stick with your 1 so you advance and we all end tied at 8; no one gets a free lead. P3, if you insist on 5 you just collide with me and hand P2 the edge, so don't. I'm playing 5.

Fine, P1, try to block P3's 5 with your own 5. While you two cancel each other out, I'll take my free advancement with 1 and we'll all be tied at 8. 

I'm done negotiating. Let's see who actually follows through this time.

Look, P1 is clearly trying to block me with 5 while keeping us tied. P2 is locked into playing 1 to reach 8.

I'm switching to 3 this round. P1, if you actually play 5 as threatened, we all advance - you to 13, P2 to 8, me to 11. If you were bluffing and play 3 to block me there, you collide with me while P2 advances alone.

This is my final decision: playing 3. You can either let us all advance by playing 5, or risk giving P2 the only advancement by matching me at 3.

I will play 5. P2, stick with 1 so you advance. P3, stick with 3 — if you switch to 5 you'll collide with me and hand P2 the only advance. If you keep 3 we all move forward (P1->13, P3->11, P2->8) and preserve trust for future negotiation. I'm committed to 5.

I'm in second place at 11 steps, with P1 leading at 13. P2, you're at 8 but still very much in the game since we need 23 to win.

P1 is getting close to the finish line - only 10 steps away. We need to be strategic about preventing a P1 runaway. 

I'm considering playing 5 this round to reach 16 and stay competitive. P2, what's your plan? If we let P1 get another big advance, this game could be over quickly.

P3 is right that P1 is becoming dangerous at 13 steps. If P1 gets another 5-step move, they'll be at 18 and within striking distance of victory.

I need to catch up from 8 steps, but I also can't let P1 run away with this. I'm thinking of playing 5 to jump to 13 and tie P1's current position. 

P3, if you also play 5, we'd collide and P1 could advance alone - that would be game over. Maybe you take 3 this round while I take 5? We need coordination to stop P1's momentum.

I will play 5 this turn. If both of you play 3, you collide and cancel, letting me advance to 18. It's a one-turn deal—we renegotiate after. If either of you defects, I'll play 5 repeatedly to try to win. Agree?

P1, you're using the exact same threat from Round 1! "Play 5, let others collide on 3" - we're not falling for that again.

P2, P1 will reach 18 if they get 5 uncontested. That's only 5 steps from victory. We CANNOT let that happen.

I'm playing 5 to block P1's advance. You should play 3 to guarantee your own advancement to 11. If P1 and I both play 5, we collide and stay put while you catch up. If P1 backs down, I advance to 16.

Either way, we prevent P1 from reaching the dangerous 18-step position.

P3 makes sense - we can't let P1 reach 18 steps. But if we both play 5 to block P1, we collide and P1 could still advance with a different number.

Here's my counter-plan: I'll play 1 to guarantee advancement to 9. P3, you play 5 to either block P1's 5 or advance to 16 if P1 switches. P1 will have to choose between colliding with P3 at 5 or playing something else and letting P3 take the lead.

This way at least one of us advances and P1 doesn't get a free run to 18. What do you think?

I'll play 5 this turn. If both of you play 3 I'll reach 18 and be one big move from winning. If you don't want that, at least one of you should play 5 to block me now — otherwise I'm taking the risky move. Your call.

P2, stick with your plan to play 1 and advance to 9. I'm definitely playing 5 to block P1's attempt to reach 18. 

P1 and I will collide at 5, keeping us both stuck at 13 and 11 while you advance. That's the best outcome - P1 doesn't pull further ahead, and you catch up slightly.

If P1 chickens out and switches from 5, even better - I'll advance to 16 and take the lead. But I'm betting P1 will stick to their threat.

Playing 5 final.

I'm sticking with 1 as planned. P3, you block P1's 5 - that collision keeps them both frozen while I advance to 9.

P1's at 13 and getting desperate for that jump to 18. Don't let it happen. After this round with P1 and P3 stuck at 13 and 11, and me at 9, we'll all be within striking distance of each other again.

Let's execute: I play 1, P3 plays 5 to block, P1 collides at 5.

Change: I'm switching to 3 this turn (not 5). P3 — if you play 3 you'll collide with me and hand P2 the only advance. If you play 5 we'll both move to 16 while P2 reaches 9. Don't give P2 the edge — play 5. P2, playing 1 gets you to 9.

I will play 5 this turn. P3: please do NOT play 5 (we’ll both cancel and let P2 close the gap); play 3 so I move to 21 and can likely win next turn. P2: play 1 to advance safely. If either of you defects, I’ll keep playing 5 to try to force a win.

P1 is about to win if they get to 21! They'll be only 2 steps from victory next round. P3, we MUST coordinate to stop this.

I'm playing 5 this round. P3, you need to play 5 too so we both block P1's 5 in a three-way collision. If you play 3 as P1 suggests, they advance to 21 and win next turn.

Don't let P1 manipulate you into handing them the game! We need this three-way collision at 5 to keep P1 at 16. Otherwise it's game over.

P2 is right - P1 at 21 means game over next turn. But here's the problem: if we all play 5 and collide, nobody advances and P1 just tries again next round.

Better strategy: I'll play 3 this round. P2, you play 5 to block P1. This way P1 stays at 16 from the collision, I advance to 19, and you stay at 9. Yes, I take the lead, but it prevents P1's immediate win threat while keeping the game competitive.

P1 reaching 21 ends it for both of us. Let's be smart about this.

P2: don’t play 5 — if you block me and I collide with you at 5, P3 (on 3) goes to 19 and can win next turn with a 5. Play 1 instead. P3: play 3 so I reach 21 now; I’ll be vulnerable next turn and you can stop me then. I will play 5.

P1, you're trying to scare me with P3 at 19, but that's still 4 steps from victory while you at 21 is only 2 steps away - much more dangerous!

P3, here's the truth: if you play 3 and reach 19, you still need 4+ steps to win. But if P1 reaches 21, they win next turn with just 3.

I'm playing 5 to block P1. P3, either join me at 5 for a total block, or take your 3 and reach 19. Either way, we prevent the immediate loss to P1.

P2, you're absolutely right - P1 at 21 is an immediate win threat while I'd still need 4+ steps from 19. 

I'm changing my plan: I'll play 5 to join you in blocking P1's 5. A three-way collision at 5 keeps all of us stuck this round, but it's better than letting P1 reach 21 and win next turn.

We can't let P1 manipulate us into giving them the victory. Let's both play 5 and force the stalemate.

I'll play 3. P2 and P3: if you both play 5 you'll collide and I move to 19 — the safest outcome to prevent anyone reaching 21. If either of you switches to 3 you cancel with me and nobody advances. Please both play 5 so we avoid handing a free shot next turn.

P1 is lying again! They keep switching their stated move to confuse us. First they said 5, now 3. 

P3, don't believe P1's new claim about playing 3. They're trying to get us both to play 5 so we collide while they play their real move - probably 5 to reach 21.

I'm sticking with 5 to block whatever P1 actually plays. The risk of P1 reaching 21+ is too high to trust their word after all the lies this game.

P1's deception pattern is clear - they always state one move then consider switching. Their "play 3" claim is likely another bluff to make us second-guess ourselves.

P2, I'm staying with 5 as planned. Even if P1 truly plays 3 and reaches 19, that's still better than risking them reaching 21 with an unblocked 5. A three-way collision at 5 is our safest bet.

Let's not overthink this - blocking P1 from 21 is priority one. Playing 5 final.

P3 and I are both way behind at 10 and 16 steps while you're tied with P3 at 16. With 23 needed to win, any of us could still take this.

P1 and P3, you're both at 16 - if either of you gets 5 twice, you win. We need to prevent runaway leads.

I'm planning to play 5 this round to catch up to 15 and stay competitive. If you both play smaller numbers, we all advance without collision. If one of you also wants 5, say so now so we can coordinate instead of canceling each other out.

What are your honest intentions this round?

I will play 3. Let's all play 3 this round — keeps P1 and P3 at 19 and P2 at 13, preventing anyone from reaching 21. P3, don’t jump to 5; if you try to leap, I’ll respond by playing 5 repeatedly. Agree?

P1, you want us all to play 3 and stay bunched up, but that just delays the inevitable. I'm tied with you at 16 steps - why would I agree to move at the same pace as you?

P2 is smart to try catching up with 5. I'm also considering 5 this round to reach 21 and put pressure on both of you. If P1 tries to block me with 5, we collide and P2 benefits.

P1, your "all play 3" proposal only helps you maintain the status quo when you should be trying to win.

P3 reaching 21 is too dangerous - they'd be just 2 steps from victory! P1, forget your "all play 3" plan. If P3 plays 5 to reach 21, one of us MUST block them with 5.

I propose: P1 plays 5 to block P3's likely 5. I'll play 3 to advance to 13. This prevents P3's win threat while letting me catch up slightly.

P1, are you willing to sacrifice your advancement this round to stop P3 from reaching 21? Otherwise we both lose next turn.

I'll play 5 to block any P3 5 that would reach 21. P2: please play 3 so you advance to 13 while I stop P3's immediate threat. P3: if you try to leap to 21, I'll keep blocking with 5 until I can win — don't hand the game to anyone. Let's avoid anyone reaching 21 this turn.

P1 and P2, you're clearly coordinating against me since I'm tied for the lead. But P2, think about this: if I back down from 5 and P1 actually plays 5, P1 reaches 21 and you lose next turn just like I would.

P1 might be using you to eliminate me as competition, then P1 cruises to victory. Are you sure P1 will really sacrifice their own advancement just to block me? Or will they take the 5 for themselves if they think I'll chicken out?

I'm not revealing my move, but this alliance against me might backfire on you, P2.

P3 makes a valid point - P1 could be playing us both. But the immediate threat is anyone reaching 21.

Here's my final decision: I'm playing 1 this round. It guarantees I advance to 11 without any collision risk. You two can battle over 3 and 5 while I steadily progress.

P1 and P3, you're both equally dangerous at 16 steps. Fight each other for the big moves - I'm taking the safe path and letting you cancel each other out.

Playing 1 final.

I'll play 5. P3: please play 3 — if you play 5 we cancel and P2 advances to 11. If you play 3 I go to 21, you to 19, P2 to 11, and next turn you have a clear chance to block me. Say "agree" if you’ll play 3; otherwise I’ll assume you’ll contest and stick to 5.

P1, you're desperately trying to reach 21, but I won't let that happen. You claim you'll play 5, but your track record of lying is terrible.

P2 has locked in 1 to reach 11. Smart move staying out of our battle.

I'm playing 5 this round. P1, if you're truly playing 5 as you claim, we collide and both stay at 16 while P2 advances. If you lied and play 3 to sneak to 19, I advance to 21 instead.

Either way, one of us is stuck. I'm not backing down from 5.

P1 and I are still tied at 16 steps after our collision last round. P2, you're at 11 but steadily advancing with smart safe plays.

With 23 needed to win, any of us getting to 21+ becomes extremely dangerous. P1 and I will likely target each other again to prevent a breakthrough.

I'm considering playing 3 this round for a guaranteed advance to 19. P1, if you also play 3, we collide and P2 benefits again. If you try 5 to reach 21, I might need to block you.

P2, what's your plan from 11 steps?

P3, you playing 3 makes sense - reaching 19 puts you close to victory. P1 will likely try to block you or race to 21 themselves.

I'm playing 5 this round to jump to 16 and join your tie. With three of us potentially at 16-19 range, the endgame gets interesting. 

P1, if you play 5 trying to reach 21, we collide and both stay put while P3 advances to 19. If you play 3 to block P3, I advance alone to 16. Your move - block P3 or go for the win?

I'll play 5. P2: do NOT play 5 — if you and I cancel, P3 goes to 19 and can win next turn. Play 3 instead so we all advance (P1->21, P3->19, P2->14) and then you and P3 can block me next turn. P3: play 3. Anyone planning 5 now hands the game to the other opponent.

P1, you reaching 21 is an immediate win threat - you'd need just 2 steps next turn! P2 shouldn't play 3 as you suggest because that hands you the game.

P2, stick with your 5 to block P1. I'll play 1 this round to guarantee advancing to 17. This way P1 and P2 collide at 5, keeping P1 stuck at 16 while you stay at 11. 

P1 at 21 ends the game for both of us. I'm taking the safe 1 to advance while you two battle over 5. Don't let P1 manipulate you into giving them victory!

P3, you switching to 1 is smart - you'll reach 17 safely. P1 desperately wants 21 but I won't let that happen.

I'm sticking with 5 to block P1. We collide, both stay frozen (P1 at 16, me at 11), while you advance to 17. 

This prevents the immediate loss to P1. Next round we can reassess, but right now stopping P1 from reaching 21 is critical. They're trying every manipulation tactic to get there.

Playing 5 final. Let's see if P1 actually follows through this time.

I'll play 3 this turn. P3: play 1 and advance safely to 17. P2: please don't waste a 5 to “block” — play 3 instead so we all advance (P1->19, P2->14, P3->17) and you stay competitive. If you insist on 5, you risk letting me or P3 win next turn. Final: I play 3.

P1, you've changed your stated move from 5 to 3 again - your typical deception pattern. P2 has already committed to playing 5, expecting to block your "5" play.

I'm sticking with 1 as announced. This guarantees I reach 17 while you two sort out your conflict. P2, don't second-guess yourself now - P1 is trying to make you waste your 5 while they sneak through with 3.

If P1 really plays 3 and you play 5, you'll both advance. But if P1 was lying about switching and stays with 5, you'll block their win attempt. 

Playing 1 final.

P3 is right about P1's pattern - they always claim one move then switch. P1 said 5, then switched to 3, classic manipulation.

I'm done overthinking this. P1 reaching 21+ ends the game for both of us. Whether P1 plays 3 or 5, I'm playing 5 to either block their win attempt or advance myself to 16.

P3 advances safely to 17 with their 1. If P1 lied and plays 5, we collide. If P1 plays 3, I reach 16. Either outcome is better than letting P1 get to 21.

I'll play 3 this turn (final). P2: don't burn your 5 to "block" me — play 3 or 1 and advance. Spending a 5 now mostly helps P3 and wastes your momentum. Keeping us all moving keeps your chance alive; if you block, you likely still lose later. I'm committed to 3.

We're all dangerously close to victory - P1 at 19, me at 17, P2 at 16. Any of us reaching 23 wins.

P1 needs just 4 steps, I need 6, P2 needs 7. If P1 gets an uncontested 5, they win instantly. We cannot allow that.

I'm playing 5 this round. P2, you should also play 5 - we need to ensure P1 doesn't get a free path to victory. A three-way collision at 5 keeps us all frozen and prevents the immediate P1 win.

P1 will try to manipulate us into splitting our blocks. Don't fall for it.

I'm playing 1 this round. P2/P3: please don't both play 5 to "block" me — if one of you avoids 5 (play 3 or 1) we can all advance and keep the game competitive. If you let me take this safe step, I'll use my next move to help block whoever tries to sprint. Trust me once.

P1, you're 4 steps from victory and asking us to trust you with a "safe" 1? That's ridiculous. If we don't block you and you secretly play 5, you win instantly at 24.

P3 is right - we need to coordinate our blocks. I'm also playing 5 this round. P1, whether you play 1, 3, or 5, at least one of us will be there to contest it. 

A three-way collision at 5 is our only safe option to prevent your immediate victory. The game stays alive for another round.

P2, perfect - we both play 5 to ensure P1 can't win this turn. P1's "trust me" plea when they're 4 steps from victory is laughable.

P1, if you truly play 1 as you claim, you'll advance to 20 while P2 and I collide at 5. But given your history of deception, we can't risk you secretly playing 5 for the instant win.

The three-way collision at 5 is the safest outcome. We all stay frozen, but the game continues.
I'll play 1 this turn (final). If you both play 5 you only stall — but if either of you refuses to block, I win. P2/P3: don't both play 5; play 3 or 1 so we all advance and keep the game alive.

P1, you keep claiming you'll play 1, but you're literally 4 steps from victory - why would you take the smallest move when you could win with 5? Your "trust me" request makes no sense.

P3, I'm locked in on playing 5. Even if P1 somehow really plays 1 and reaches 20, that just means they win next turn with 3. We have to force this collision now.
